job_title: Anonymous Employee in Jefferson City, MO
pros: The only good thing about this job other than the stable hours, are some of the people I work with.
cons: There is a lot of butt kissing in this company, a lot of favoritism and special treatment for the chosen few. They may call themselves catholic, but the only real evidence of that I can see is that they won't cover birth control and they all seem to want to drink. Recently they started this new practice of not hiring people who smoke. I don't smoke, but I think that's wrong. What a person does on their own time is their own business. It's a joke anyway. It just causes new hires who do smoke to lie about it. They have created chaos by changing our operating system and keep piling more work onto us while taking away workers and still expect us to get things done while constantly inturrupting with special "meetings" that are meaningless. We have to do more with less. Then get in trouble when we can't keep up. They've taken our benefits and turned them into a three ring circus. We have to jump through hoops just to keep them, now we're going to get docked $50 a paycheck if we want to cover a working spouse or child. They don't listen to the workers. It's all about how much the uppercrust can make. I'm sure some CEO needs to pay for his summer home and new boat.

review_title: Work here only if homelessness is imminent
pros: The only pro for St Mary's is that it's a great place for young RN's to get their first job.
cons: St Mary's at one time was a good place to work (before CHE/TH took over). The CEO/CFO have left in the last 12 months and current/interim leadership is worthless. If you want a position that offers growth, look at other employers. In addition, wages at SMH are well below national average across the whole hospital. The best thing for morale at the hospital would be a buyout. Emory was looking at the hospital, but backed out. Everyone was hoping that acquisition would've happened. Corporate pushes too much nonsense and the executives don't have enough brass to stand up for what's right (and the people).
